title: Whitworth Hall Country Park Walking Route

images.title: rob bishop / Whitworth Hall Country Park
images.caption: Three deer line up to pose for the camera with the lake in the background.

images.title: P Glenwright / Deer near water feature at Whitworth Hall Co Durham
images.caption: Deer near water feature. Whitworth Hall was the home of Bobby Shaftoe. Shaftoe was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons between 1760 and 1790. He was the likely subject of a famous North East English folk song and nursery rhyme "Bobby Shafto's Gone to Sea"

images.title: View from Whitworth Hall by Alex McGregor, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Luch parkland in late summer.

images.title: Arbour rear of Whitworth Hall Hotel by Alex McGregor, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Secluded Arbour in the woods to the rear of the hall.

images.title: Lake with mock ruins, Whitworth Hall Country Park by Alex McGregor, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lake with mock ruins

description: Explore 73 acres of parkland surrounding the Grade II listed stately mansion of Whitworth Hall in Spennymoor. You can hand feed the resident fallow deer, stroll around the ornamental lake and then follow the peaceful woodland walk. There is also a pretty Victorian garden containing England's most northerly vineyard. The Weardale Way walking route runs along the River Wear just to the north of the park. This waymarked long distance trail is a great option if you would like to continue your walking in the area.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The Auckland Walk can be picked up just to the south of the hall in Spennymoor. You can follow this shared cycling and walking trail south along a disused railway line to Bishop Auckland. Here you can enjoy some pleasant riverside walks and visit the old castle where there's more interesting history and parkland to explore.

display_address: Stanner's Lane, Newtown Farm, Byers Green, Spennymoor, County Durham, North East, England, DL16 7QX, United Kingdom
